Dr. Malcolm Sayer.Action: Examines Leonard's deteriorating handwriting carefully and notices a pattern of decline.
Tries to maintain a good-natured smile despite confusion and apparent dismissiveness from the Director and Chief of Medicine.
Appears uncomfortable and confused about the nature of the position and the institutional setting, showing some lack of confidence in the moment.
Responds honestly and straightforwardly about his prior research experience with earthworms, rather than inflating or fabricating expertise.
Admits to failure in his earthworm myelin extraction project after five years and acknowledges others were right.
Demonstrates self-awareness by recognizing he is not the right fit for the job due to lack of clinical background and attempts to leave gracefully.
Shows lack of confidence by expressing feelings of not belonging and wishing to leave the interview early.
Hesitates and is unsure about accepting the job offer, thinking about it long and hard.
Manages a reluctant nod and shrug when faced with pressure from the Director.
Extends his hand for a handshake, attempting a polite greeting.
Tries to calm a woman in a wheelchair who is screaming, speaking gently and showing patience.
Responds to a loud, confrontational patient calmly without visible irritation.
Hesitates and shows uncertainty when Mrs. Cohen asks if he is there for her, indicating sensitivity and carefulness.
Tries to find the discharge form but is unsuccessful and must ask a nurse about Mrs. Cohen's son; shows discomfort in delivering bad news.
Attempts to open a jammed window to get fresh air, showing persistence and presence of mind.
Carefully cleans and adjusts the patient's damaged glasses despite their poor condition, demonstrating attention to detail and gentle handling.
Repeatedly attempts to communicate with a profoundly unresponsive patient by asking questions and observing reactions, showing persistence and observational skill.
Turns away from patient to type at a manual typewriter, implying organized documentation of observations.
Uses uncleaned thick lenses, possibly indicative of neglect in personal equipment maintenance.
Carefully adjusts and replaces the patient's bent and loose glasses with gentleness and patience.
Observes subtly that the patient has moved despite appearing immobile, showing careful attention to detail.
Waits patiently after placing the glasses on the floor to see if the patient will retrieve them, demonstrating thoughtful observation and patience.
States facts about the patient's condition to other doctors, showing knowledge and skill in communication.
Stares at the patient in apparent surprise after she lunges for the glasses, which might indicate momentary astonishment but also attentive reaction.
Types findings and diagnosis carefully into the admissions form, indicating thoroughness and professionalism.
Recites a mental checklist aloud as he prepares to leave, showing a ritual to focus or remember steps before driving.
Slams on brakes abruptly when someone raps on the window, indicating possible distraction or momentary lapse in attention.
Responds politely and with gratitude to Miss Costello's expression of support despite momentary blankness, showing social awareness and humility.
Stares blankly after Miss Costello departs and seems lost in thought, perhaps indicating internal confusion or distraction.
Sits alone for dinner without something to read or engage with, appearing inattentive or disconnected.
Nods in agreement to patient's claim about hearing a voice, showing openness to patient experience.
Questions the patient carefully and calmly about the voice, showing clinical curiosity and presence of mind.
Denies being the source of the voice and asserts it wasn't real, demonstrating rational skepticism and professional caution.
Appears taken aback and surprised when accused by Sidney, indicating momentary uncertainty.
Seems distracted and lost in thought while standing in the cafeteria line, possibly indicating preoccupation or lack of focus.
Notices a patient previously overlooked and attempts a practical solution to communicate with Mr. Titch, showing observational skill and problem-solving ability.
His smile fades when he realizes Sidney is still in a predicament and he does not have the answer yet, indicating an awareness of his current limitations but also a lack of immediate solution.
Patiently waits to be connected on phone, apologizes multiple times during call, careful to communicate despite difficulty.
Requests installation of a big lock urgently for safety, showing concern for others.
Keeps the phone receiver to his ear while moving to the patient, maintaining the call and thinking ahead about installing a lock urgently to secure the area.
Misdialed or made some mistake on the call and needed to apologize and correct himself before proceeding.
Moves table and wheelchair to clear obstacles in front of patient, trying to help her walk.
Fills a paper cup and brings water to the patient when she stops moving despite no barriers.
Recognizes the obstacles preventing the patient from moving, physically removes objects (table, wheelchair) to clear path, observes patient’s behavior carefully.
Accepts patient’s stopping and defeats and brings water to her when she cannot complete the movement, showing sensitivity but also a willingness to help practically.
Systematically reviews old patient files and admission forms seeking original diagnoses, demonstrating thoroughness and attention to detail.
Politely declines Miss Costello's invitation for coffee or tea, giving a vague excuse but maintaining cordial tone.
Engages thoughtfully in pondering patients' diagnoses, showing a calm and reflective demeanor.
Orders tea politely and shows calm composure in a mundane social interaction (ordering from waiter).
Collects specialized books from antiquarian shops, suggesting effort to deepen knowledge and research.
Carefully studies an old first edition book with drawings of primitive life forms, showing intellectual curiosity and scholarly dedication.
Surrounds himself with many medical and nature-related books, organized in a way that indicates intensive study and research.
Plays piano in a modest home setting, suggesting a cultured or creative mind, which may indirectly support mental acuity but does not directly reflect medical competence.
Falls asleep with an open medical book and reading glasses on his chest, indicating dedication but possibly exhaustion or lack of rest which could negatively impact competence.
Explains kindly to the janitor about patients' history of encephalitis despite janitor's lack of understanding.
Observes and reviews decades-old research and footage to understand a mysterious illness, showing thoroughness and dedication.
Listens carefully to older doctors' experiences and historical information to gain insight into patients' conditions.
Observes patients carefully and thoughtfully, asking insightful questions about their mental states.
Shows hope and persistence in understanding the condition despite limited information from colleagues.
Engages personally with patients, attempting controlled interactions like having them catch a ball and observing responses.
Acknowledges his and others' lack of complete knowledge without premature conclusions or false confidence.
Carefully observes multiple patients with attention to detail, noting subtle patient behaviors and differences in their responses.
Engages in thoughtful reflection on ambiguous patient behavior, asking penetrating questions about intent and understanding.
Overanalyzes a patient's poor test result, hypothesizing about willful failure which others see as unlikely.
Carefully observes patient behavior and art, looking for deeper meaning in symptoms.
Momentarily distracted by another patient while with Leonard and his mother.
Nods uncertainly when patient's mother praises Leonard's drawing, indicating some doubt or lack of clear interpretation.
Ignores the patients' ball game, stuck at a dead end with limited success.
Sits alone staring blankly out the window, reflecting on normal life outside.
Works on the floor with Miss Costello, filling missing tiles to restore a pattern despite patients and nurses ignoring/paying no attention.
Gently lifts Lucy and guides her to walk over the tiles, observing her hesitation and progress closely.
Suppresses his emotional reaction and maintains a professional mask to focus on patient progress.
Notices unforeseen details such as the broken window pane and interprets patient behavior as evidence of cognitive engagement.
Attempts to engage Leonard vocally by encouraging him to speak his name, showing patience and observation.
Waits silently while Leonard does not respond, demonstrating patience rather than frustration.
Shows intrigue and engagement when Fernando discusses patients' reactions to music and recognizes subtle emotional responses.
Carries an 8mm camera and filming equipment suggesting preparation and initiative to document patient behavior.
Responds empathetically to the MS Woman who feels ignored, demonstrating interpersonal skills and emotional intelligence.
His expression changes when observing Miss Costello walking a patient, indicating he recognizes a new insight or breakthrough.
Carefully, awkwardly places his hands on Leonard's, seeking connection and communication despite uncertainty.
Speaks aloud to Leonard with hopeful, encouraging words during the Ouija board attempt.
Shows patience and persistence despite Leonard's unclear responses and his own uncertainty.
Carefully and persistently attempts to communicate with Leonard using the Ouija Board, showing patience and innovative effort.
Expresses hopeful and foolish feelings, unsure if Leonard understands instructions clearly.
Admits fault when communication is unclear, attempts to correct himself and improve clarity.
Realizes the patient is spelling out a word and quickly writes it down to analyze it further.
Deciphers the nonsensical string into 'RILKE s/p ANTHER' and actively follows up by cross-referencing at the library to understand it.
Uses external resources like the public library to research Rainer Maria Rilke after recognizing the patient's spelling is connected to the poet.
Interrupts a neurochemist's presentation awkwardly by prematurely raising his hand and speaking out of turn.
Seems socially awkward and uncomfortable in the professional setting, failing to navigate the crowd and unable to approach the neurochemist directly.
Takes initiative by following the neurochemist alone into a men's room to ask a highly specialized and thoughtful question about Parkinsonian tremor.
Demonstrates Parkinsonian symptoms himself to explain a concept, actively engaging in dynamic, illustrative communication.
Engages respectfully but confidently debates his supervisor Kaufman about the premature dismissal of L-Dopa treatment efficacy.
Shows some hesitation and falls behind his supervisor while trying to keep up, indicating possible lack of assertiveness or confidence in the interaction.
Acknowledges and anticipates negative professional opinions but continues to pursue his perspective, demonstrating persistence and thoughtful judgment.
Firmly asserts his belief in the patients' internal life despite skepticism, influencing Kaufman to reconsider his stance.
Engages in a confident, reasoned exchange addressing risks and benefits of the drug with a senior colleague.
Pushes for the chance to treat at least one patient despite institutional limitations and wariness from superiors.
Considers lying to Kaufman but chooses honesty when questioned about his lab supervisor's reaction.
Explains to Mrs. Lowe patiently and gently about Leonard's condition and the medication's uncertain effects, despite her confusion.
Consents to proceed with a risky project despite previous lab supervisor rejection, showing perseverance and willingness to take responsibility.
Explains the biochemical basis of Parkinson-like symptoms with some clarity, demonstrating scientific knowledge and ability to communicate complex ideas.
Admits uncertainty about the effects of the medicine on the patient honestly to Mrs. Lowe, showing intellectual honesty but revealing limits of current knowledge.
Hesitates and struggles physically (shaking hands) while handling a cup, which may indicate nervousness or lack of confidence in the moment.
Smiles politely at the patients' interactions and humor, showing social awareness and empathy.
Shows uncertainty when questioned about Leonard's awareness of the time lost, nodding uncertainly rather than confidently.
Observes patient motor control carefully and encourages Leonard with praise ('Splendid'), then makes a note, demonstrating attentive clinical skills and documentation.
Seeks something to offer his guest despite being exhausted.
Admits feeling uncomfortable about a personal photograph.
Explains patiently and in detail the purpose of different pairs of glasses to Leonard.
Organizes multiple pairs of glasses each with a specific purpose and explains their use thoughtfully.
Is exhausted and struggles to find simple refreshments for his guest, rummaging through packing boxes.
Admits feeling uncomfortable when discussing a personal photograph but continues engaging with his guest.
Demonstrates practical foresight by preparing and organizing multiple pairs of glasses to handle different vision needs cautiously.
Admits recognizing the unpredictability and difficulty of certain situations like going for walks, showing realistic self-awareness without overconfidence.

Shows social awkwardness by apologizing for an 'inelegant presentation' and admitting he does not entertain much, which may imply lack of confidence in social skills but not necessarily clinical competence.
Reflects thoughtfully on his childhood interest in science and finds comfort in the predictability of elements, indicating intellectual depth and a methodical mindset.
Feels exposed and somewhat vulnerable when personal topics arise, indicating some social discomfort but no clear impact on professional competence.
Admits he is not good with people but expresses liking and wishing to understand them better.
Feels uneasy and uncomfortable when told others see him as kind and caring.
Appears blank and somewhat disconnected when others mention people who know him well.
Avoids responding to subtle social cues and changes the subject to leave.
Admits openly that he is 'not terribly good with people' and has only a rudimentary understanding of them.
Uncomfortable and uncertain when others praise his kindness, especially when it conflicts with his own self-assessment.
Describes Leonard's condition with empathy and explains facial masking should not be confused with apathy.
Acknowledges the rare but significant human connections that briefly awaken Leonard (mention of name, music, touch).
Maintains a scientific tone with the board and audience, showing restraint and respect when asked to speak less scientifically.
Presents before-and-after footage of a patient (Leonard) showing clear improvement, demonstrating understanding and progress of treatment.
Observes and acknowledges patients volunteering in the pharmacy setting, indicating awareness and engagement with patient involvement.
Exchanges a meaningful glance with Miss Costello after audience donates money, showing professional communication and modesty rather than self-promotion.
Sits and waits despite knowing nothing immediate will happen, showing patience and restraint.
Wakes promptly when called by the night nurse and responds professionally.
Carries himself with sobriety and restraint along with other staff, indicating professionalism.
Displays visible awe and wonder at the patients’ awakening, suggesting emotional investment and human insight.
Tries to engage with Lucy by asking what year it is, showing awareness and effort to connect and assess her condition.
Hesitates and struggles to smile when Lucy smiles, indicating possible discomfort or uncertainty in social interaction.
Responds to Sidney's question about the reality of the awakenings with confident affirmation: 'As real as real can be.'
Confirms to Sidney that the emotional connection with Lolly is 'As real as real can be,' providing reassurance with confident and compassionate communication.
Encourages Leonard to go on the field trip and stays engaged with his choices.
Waves to Leonard after Leonard refuses to go, following his lead patiently.
Considers various recreational options for patients, such as the opera house and Botanical Gardens, showing effort to engage patients thoughtfully.
Appears somewhat uncertain and looks to others (Anthony) for validation or guidance about patients' preferences.
Smiles at Rose when she approaches, though the smile fades as she sings to him.
Embarrassed but allows Rose to pull him out to dance despite being mortified and feeling watched.
Pauses to listen carefully when hearing typing down the corridor; shows observational attentiveness.
Peers over Leonard's shoulder and smiles at the typewritten list, indicating understanding and encouragement.
Reads Leonard's detailed and organized suggestions aloud at the board meeting, demonstrating clear communication and advocacy.
Supports progressive patient-centered ideas like education, recreation, grievances, and equality in hospital food, showing insight and thoughtfulness.
Does not speak after reading Leonard's list at the board meeting, listening quietly to the silence that follows.
Responds to confusion with sincerity, tries to clear up misunderstanding politely.
Attempts a good-natured smile to share in the Director's amusement despite not understanding it fully.
Buries potentially negative detail (earthworms research) rather than boasting or being defensive.
Acknowledges his lack of suitable clinical background and tries to leave respectfully, showing humility and consideration for others' time.
Mentions his past research in a straightforward, unembellished way without boasting or defensiveness.
Feels out of place and wishes he were somewhere else, indicating self-awareness but also insecurity.
Hesitates visibly and is unsettled by the Director's broad smile and handshake offer.
Thinks long and hard about accepting the job at the chronic hospital treating severely ill patients.
Responds courteously to the patient greeting with 'I guess not.'
Attempts to find discharge papers for Mrs. Cohen, shows visible discomfort in delivering disappointing news, returns to her to try to communicate gently.
Tries to open the window to let fresh air in, appears to seek comfort after difficult interaction.
Speaks gently to the unresponsive patient multiple times, attempts to connect despite no response.
Carefully removes and cleans the patient's bent, uncomfortable glasses and puts them back on her face.
Turns away to type at a manual typewriter immediately after attending to patient without lingering or showing emotional expression.
Gently adjusts patient's glasses and patiently waits as she tries to retrieve them, showing attentiveness and care.
Stares silently and entranced at the patient, indicating a sincere emotional engagement.
Provides detailed background on the patient to colleagues, showing a conscientious concern for understanding her condition.
Throws a tennis ball to a patient and expresses delight at her catching it, showing engagement and hope.
Responds to Kaufman's skepticism with polite disagreement, unaware that it offends Kaufman.
Responds politely and sincerely to Miss Costello's offer of help by thanking her quietly and watching her leave with appreciation.
Mumbles a counting ritual to himself while preparing to drive, indicating possible social awkwardness or internal preoccupation, but no clear warmth indicator.
Eats dinner alone at a restaurant and appears absorbed in his own thoughts, showing no social engagement but no negative warmth indicator either.
Engages cautiously but sincerely with Sidney, asking questions to understand his experience and denying involvement respectfully.
Responds to Sidney's sly accusation with disbelief and maintains polite distance, showing respect despite tension.
Nods absentmindedly and leaves his tray, seemingly distracted and lost in thought, not engaging with the conversation.
Asks Sidney if he saw him speak, showing an attempt at interaction and connection.
Notices an elderly woman in a wheelchair only when Sidney is feeding her carefully, showing delayed attention to others' needs.
Smiles, pleased with his solution to comfort Mr. Titch, showing effort to reassure him.
His smile fades when Sidney is still in a predicament and Sayer has no answer, revealing vulnerability and concern.
Engages respectfully and patiently with the old doctor, showing concern about patients and their condition.
Offers to get the nurse for the old doctor when he seems unwell, showing attentiveness and care.
Finds five patients potentially suffering from the unique disease, indicating investigative effort and knowledge.
Shows concern for the old doctor’s condition and hesitates before offering help, demonstrating sensitivity but also uncertainty.
Engages respectfully with the old doctor, seeking hard-to-obtain information about a rare disease, indicating persistence and professional curiosity.
Speaks gently to Leonard's mother, acknowledges nonverbal communication with Leonard
Shows patience and concern by bringing water to Lucy, a patient stuck at the drinking fountain
Nods uncertainly when Mrs. Lowe praises Leonard's drawing, indicating humility and shared encouragement
Wanders off quietly after being ignored by Mrs. Lowe, holding a paper cup he brought for her.
Arrives unannounced at Mrs. Lowe's apartment and expresses genuine curiosity to know more about Leonard.
Nods uncertainly when faced with a critical comment from Mrs. Lowe and does not respond effectively.
Takes the hint and wanders off silently, appearing passive and unsure.
Arrives unannounced at Mrs. Lowe’s apartment and expresses clear intent to learn more about Leonard.
Listens attentively to Mrs. Lowe's detailed account of Leonard’s childhood and condition.
Shows interest and respect by attentively observing Leonard's condition and asking Mrs. Lowe thoughtful questions about Leonard's life during his illness.
Glances away from Mrs. Lowe occasionally, appearing distracted or detached.
Firmly insists to Dr. Mann that he is working with living patients, signaling sincerity and commitment.
Considers working with living patients at a poor chronic hospital rather than doing autopsies, indicating a willingness to serve the underserved and a commitment to clinical work.
Does not respond to Mann's disparaging remark about lowering himself to clinical work, showing restraint and tolerance.
Responds to Mann's angry slap with no visible retaliation or anger, indicating patience and self-control.
Engages gently with Hank the monkey, allowing it to play and presses the stopwatch to time the monkey’s performance, showing interest and friendly engagement.
Explains technical EEG results patiently and sincerely to Mann despite Mann's confusion and skepticism.
Shows honest uncertainty about interpretation of EEG ('I don't know').
Correctly interprets EEG readings contrary to colleague's assumption, demonstrating accurate understanding of brain activity patterns.
Admits uncertainty ('I don't know') when questioned about the meaning of EEG signals beyond his interpretation.
Reaches a dead end in his medical efforts, recognizing his only accomplishment is limited to facilitating patients' ball-catching.
Spends time meticulously restoring the checkerboard floor pattern by filling in missing tiles with shoe polish, demonstrating patience and attention to detail.
Is observed staring blankly out the window, appearing tired and possibly mentally fatigued.
Works alongside Miss Costello to bridge the gap in the tiled floor, showing willingness to engage practically and collaboratively.
Lifts Lucy gently out of her chair and guides her to the drinking fountain, watching her progress with quiet emotional restraint.
Buries his emotions behind a professional mask instead of expressing them openly.
Patiently tries to engage Leonard by encouraging him to speak his name despite Leonard's muteness.
Listens attentively to Leonard and waits quietly for a response without showing frustration.
Shows personal involvement by playing classical music at home, indicating thoughtful preparation for patient enjoyment.
Shows genuine interest and engagement in patients' responses to music; tells the MS patient 'That's not true' when she feels ignored.
Watches Margaret and patients playing cards with delight, engaging quietly with their behavior.
Peers curiously into dayroom upon hearing music, responds to patient's thumbs-up with acknowledgment.
Observes the card game carefully and questions if it is a real game, showing curiosity and attention to patient behavior.
Expresses delight at the patients engaging in multiple card games, indicating an ability to appreciate complex patient interactions.
Moves among patients and notices details like the music playing and patients' reactions, suggesting situational awareness and engagement.
Observes Miss Costello's gentle and caring interaction with patient, appears moved and thoughtful, as if something she said or did unlocked a door for him
Carefully deciphers Leonard's spelling despite difficulty, showing patience and determination to understand.
Takes time to research Rilke at the public library, indicating sincere effort to connect with patient's references.
Persistently tries to engage his supervisor Kaufman in discussion despite dismissive and somewhat condescending responses.
Hurries to keep up with Kaufman and shows respect by acknowledging 'with all due respect' even when disagreeing.
Slows down and distances himself after Kaufman dismisses his views and leaves without further engagement.
Expresses hope to bring patient back to the world, acknowledges uncertainty but shows concern
Reassures Leonard by explaining about the medicine gently, considers patient's experience
Uncertain about dosage and effect, openly admits lack of knowledge
Admits uncertainty about the effects and appropriate dosage of the medicine, but suggests starting cautiously and collaborates with the pharmacist.
Expresses hope and empathy for the patient despite uncertain outcomes.
Hesitates and shows lack of concrete knowledge on the treatment but proceeds with logical, careful steps.
Watches patiently and waits with Leonard's mother and Miss Costello for signs of improvement, showing support and calm presence.
Offers reassurance to Mrs. Lowe by telling her he'll call if there's any change, indicating reliability and sincerity.
Experiments carefully with doses and mediums (milk instead of orange juice), showing concern and dedication to patient care.
Nods silently to Ray’s caution to not push it, showing restraint and collaboration rather than impatience or dominance.
Carefully adjusts the medication dosage and considers different methods of administering it when initial attempts show no effect.
Shows patience and continues observing the patient and family without premature conclusions despite lack of immediate results.
Does not push or dismiss team members' concerns or interpretations, as seen when acknowledging Ray's caution.
Stays with Leonard overnight, holding the glass to Leonard's lips and ensuring he drinks the medication, then falls asleep in the wheelchair nearby.
Sits silently opposite Leonard as Leonard struggles to speak, sharing a quiet, attentive moment with him.
When Miss Costello offers to stay if needed, Sayer replies 'Yes, I'll call' but ultimately stays alone and devoted at Leonard's side.
Gently asks Leonard permission before moving his paper, showing respect for his autonomy.
Informs Leonard that his mother is present, facilitating an emotional reunion.
Supports Leonard's interactions with others, such as Miss Costello and Margaret, encouraging social engagement.
Gently moves Leonard's paper to help him focus on his own name; recognizes significance of Leonard's waking state.
Informs Leonard of his mother's visit with calm reassurance and allows natural, emotional reunion to take place.
Facilitates social interaction between Leonard and other patients/staff, encouraging Leonard's engagement despite his struggles.
Smiles when observing patients and their interactions, shows emotional sensitivity to Leonard's reaction about lost time.
Nods uncertainly when asked if Leonard realizes the passage of time, indicating empathy and honesty.
Reassures Leonard and Mrs. Lowe by promising that sleep will come and that Leonard will wake up the next morning; smiles to assure them.
Observes Leonard attentively and with empathy as he looks at the photograph of himself, recognizing the difficult truth of his condition.
Greets Leonard warmly and engages him in friendly conversation.
Gives Leonard history books and tells him he can read them at his own leisure.
Smiles encouragingly at Leonard and shows patience and kindness.
Acknowledges Leonard's enthusiasm and tries to accommodate his wishes realistically.
Greets Leonard warmly and provides him with books to engage his mind, showing thoughtful patient care and attentiveness.
Smiles reassuringly and attempts to manage Leonard's desires realistically, balancing empathy with practical limits.
Does not rush Leonard, allows him to absorb information and take it at his own pace.
Allows Leonard to experience the world around him freely, with quiet observation and appreciation, showing patience and gentle attentiveness.
Buckles Leonard's seatbelt for him and shows him how to operate the car, demonstrating care and support.
Plays classical music in the car to create a soothing, pleasant atmosphere for Leonard.
Allows Leonard to experience and re-engage with the world gently and thoughtfully, demonstrating patience and care.
Performs the 'complex' preparatory sequence to start the car, showing technical familiarity and confidence.
Observes Leonard's reactions attentively and participates in appreciating natural wonders, indicating emotional intelligence and awareness.
Prepares tea with mismatched cups and offers it despite feeling he doesn't entertain much.
Shares a personal childhood memory about finding comfort in the periodic table, showing vulnerability.
Shows a quiet, sincere moment of connection and smiles when asked about personal life.
Suggests speaking to the hospital patrons to raise funds for expensive medication, showing concern for patient care despite costs.
Unintentionally uses an impudent tone when discussing convincing patrons to give more money, but corrects himself calmly.
Proposes an innovative, if costly, treatment plan (using L-Dopa at Mr. Lowe's dosage) despite expected institutional resistance.
Acknowledges financial constraints and realistically discusses fundraising challenges with Kaufman, showing pragmatic understanding of institutional challenges.
Uses a potentially overconfident tone when suggesting convincing patrons to increase donations, but quickly corrects himself to a more diplomatic approach.
Presents a detailed, clinically accurate description of Leonard's condition to the Board, using appropriate medical terminology and clarifying misconceptions (e.g., facial masking versus apathy).
Responds positively and professionally to feedback from Miss Costello by adjusting his language to be less scientific.
Maintains composure and confidence while presenting emotionally difficult material to an audience including hospital officials and patrons.
Shows visible satisfaction and approval ('Wonderful') about neighborhood volunteers helping in the hospital.
Shares emotional experience with board members and patrons touched by Leonard's awakening, exchanging a knowing glance with Miss Costello.
Sits and waits patiently despite knowing nothing immediate will happen.
Sleeps on a too-short couch in the staff room, showing dedication and endurance.
Moves along silently but with increasing emotional involvement at the awakening of patients, showing awe and connection.
Peers into the ward with other staff, sharing in wonder and hope as patients awaken.
Helps Lucy come out of her confused state by engaging gently and asking what year it is.
Shows concern and attention when Miriam urgently calls him and a group gathers, indicating responsiveness.
Hesitates to smile at Lucy but tries, showing sincerity and an effort to connect emotionally.
Gives Sidney a sincere and reassuring answer about the reality of Lolly's awakening, offering emotional support.
Thinks of a good place to take patients dressed up with nowhere to go, showing concern for their well-being and desire to engage them.
Looks after Leonard with a friendly, attentive gaze as Leonard departs, indicating a caring and attentive nature.
Gets gently corrected and led away by Miss Costello after wandering off, showing a mildly absent-minded or distracted side but no negative warmth implication.
Thinks quickly when realizing he has no plan and then comes up with a good place for the patients to go.
Absentminded or unprepared momentarily, not knowing where to take his patients initially.
Engages Anthony in conversation at a natural history museum, showing interest in his feelings and thoughts.
Notices Miss Costello's irritation and attempts to include her by commenting on Anthony's feelings, using a gentle, humorous tone.
Engages in planning an outing considering others' preferences, checks with Anthony and Miss Costello
Attempts to get bartender's attention, showing effort to enable social interaction at the dancehall
Listens to Leonard's typed suggestions for patient improvements with a slow smile, showing appreciation and respect.
Reads patient Leonard's requests aloud to the board with supportive commentary, advocating for patient needs.
Does not interrupt or dismiss Leonard's efforts to contribute ideas for patient welfare.
